subanswer.text: It means that no matter which real number you pick for $y$, you should be able to find at least one $x$ so that $f(x)=y$. The answer is that no matter which real number you pick for y, you should be able to find at least one x so that f(x)=y.

To maximize $a$, we want to make the two parts of the piecewise definition as close together as possible, while still making sure that the quadratic part of the function is never less than the linear part. Notice that we do not need to worry about what happens when the input exceeds the variable $a$ because the parabola will always lie above the line regardless of how large the input is.

In particular, we want $2a=a^2$. Rearranging terms, this is equivalent to the equation $a^2-2a=0$. Factoring out the $a$, we obtain \begin{align*}
a^2-2a&=0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a(a-2)&=0\\
\Rightarrow\qquad a=0,\qquad a&=2
\end{align*}

Of course, this would make sense because we would expect a maximum somewhere in between those two values. Thus, our desired maximum value of $a$ is $\boxed{2}.$ The answer is: 2.
